message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the rash and the age suggest atopic dermatitis, also known as eczema. The most appropriate next step in management is to use topical emollients to provide relief from pruritus and to moisturize the skin. Topical coal tar is used in conditions such as psoriasis, oral acyclovir for viral infections like herpes, and oral vitamin A for conditions such as vitamin A deficiency or acne.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The dry and scaly patches are indicative of eczema or atopic dermatitis, which is common in infants. Topical emollients such as moisturizing creams or ointments are recommended as the first step in management. Coal tar is used for psoriasis and acyclovir is used for viral infections. Oral vitamin A is only used in severe cases and under the guidance of a dermatologist.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and presentation of dry and scaly patches suggest atopic dermatitis, which is common in infants with a family history of asthma. Topical emollients, such as moisturizing creams, are the first-line treatment for mild cases of atopic dermatitis. Topical coal tar is used for psoriasis and not recommended in infants. Oral acyclovir is used for viral infections and not indicated in this case. Oral vitamin A has not been shown to be effective for atopic dermatitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The dry and scaly patches on the face and extensor surfaces of the extremities suggest atopic dermatitis, a common form of eczema in infants. Topical emollient is the most appropriate next step in management to provide relief and moisture to the affected areas. Topical coal tar is not indicated for atopic dermatitis, oral acyclovir is indicated for viral infections, and oral vitamin A is not typically used to manage atopic dermatitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The dry, scaly patches on the face and extremities with pruritus suggest atopic dermatitis. The most appropriate next step in management would be to use topical emollients to moisturize and soothe the affected areas. Topical coal tar is used for psoriasis, oral acyclovir is used for viral infections, and oral vitamin A is used for certain skin conditions but is not the first-line treatment for atopic dermatitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and distribution of the rash suggest atopic dermatitis, which is often treated with topical emollients to hydrate and soothe the skin. Topical coal tar can be used for other types of dermatitis, but it may cause photosensitivity in infants. Oral acyclovir is used for viral infections, which are not suspected in this case. Oral vitamin A is not recommended for atopic dermatitis in infants.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The dry and scaly patches on the face and extensor surfaces of the extremities suggest eczema or atopic dermatitis. The treatment for this is to keep the skin hydrated with topical emollients. Topical coal tar can be used for psoriasis, not for atopic dermatitis. Acyclovir is used for viral infections, not related to eczema. Vitamin A is used for certain skin conditions but not for atopic dermatitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Based on the symptoms and examination findings, the most likely diagnosis is atopic dermatitis (eczema), which is a chronic relapsing skin disorder characterized by pruritic eczematous lesions. Topical emollient is the most appropriate next step as it helps to moisturize the skin and reduce itching. Topical coal tar is not appropriate as it is not usually recommended for infants. Oral acyclovir is not appropriate as there is no indication of a viral infection. Oral vitamin A is not appropriate as it can be toxic in high doses and is not generally recommended for atopic dermatitis management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The dry and scaly patches on the face and extensor surfaces of the extremities suggest eczema. The most appropriate next step in management would be to use a topical emollient to keep the skin hydrated and reduce itching. Topical coal tar is used for psoriasis. Oral acyclovir is used for herpes simplex or varicella-zoster virus infections. Oral vitamin A is used for vitamin A deficiency or as a treatment for certain skin conditions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The dry and scaly patches on the face and extensor surfaces of the extremities with sparing of the groin suggest atopic dermatitis. The most appropriate next step in management would be to use topical emollients to moisturize the affected areas and relieve the itchiness. Coal tar is used to treat psoriasis, acyclovir is used to treat herpes infections, and vitamin A is used for other dermatological conditions.
